column4: one more question please, how do i view my ubuntu from Windows? I am on a dual boot.
that would be fine, read and write into my files, but how? please? :)
I'm not sure if there is any ways of writing without losing permissions, but if you want to just view there is Linux Reader by diskinternals. (assuming you're using ext3)
there is a driver for ext3 but it messes up the permissions
am i going to loose the permissions even if i got my windows repaired?
I missed part of the earlier conversation. please explain. Are you trying to work with linux files out of windows or the other way around?
yes, view my linux files from windows environment. I know how to read my windows ( Documents) from hardy
what did you mean even if you get your windows repaired?
I mean, if my Windows crashes, this will mess up with my files.. right? but repairing windows is going to fix the issue again? am I right. sorry I am kinda new into this.
I meant that if you use the windows ext2/ext3 driver you lose the access permissions on the linux files you modify. (such as read only to all but root)
if you just want to look, but not change, explore2fs or linux reader can help.
& nickrud: http://www.diskinternals.com/linux-reader/ (linux reader, stand alone program) or http://www.chrysocome.net/explore2fs (explore2fs, integrates into explorer)
hey thanks. lemmes have a look :)
